block.p: FOR CHILDREN
Theater

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. The elaborate puppets range from a pugnacious preschooler who has sprouted wings to a dragonfly resembling Mae West. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $12; $6 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''THE ADVENTURES OF MAYA THE BEE,'' told through rod and shadow puppets and a jazz score, is about a little bee who rejects toiling in the hive and flies off to pursue tastes more exotic than honey. The elaborate puppets range from a pugnacious preschooler who has sprouted wings to a dragonfly resembling Mae West. Saturdays at 11 a.m. at the Salon Theater, 45 Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village. Tickets: $12; $6 for children. Reservations: (212) 539-6644.

''DOO-WOP DRACULA,'' a 1950's-style musical by William Electric Black about teenage love and rebellion, features a 22-member cast and 13 musical numbers. The show asks whether happiness is possible between an Italian and a Transylvanian when a plain Jane falls in love with Johnny Rave, a rebel who is dangerous not because he's a vampire but because he's different. Musical arrangements are by the reed player Harry Mann, and choreography is by Sandra Kaufmann. Sundays at 5 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays at 10 p.m. La Mama, 74A East Fourth Street. Tickets: $12. Information: (212) 475-7710.

''LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD/LA CAPERUCITA ROJA,'' a bilingual musical play (performed simultaneously in Spanish and English), written and directed by Manuel Antonio Moran, tells the story with a twist. Riding Hood does not believe the wolf is a wolf, which leads the wolf to have an identity crisis. With Jose Lopez, puppeteer. Saturdays at 3:30 p.m. and Sundays at 2 p.m. Los Kabayitos Theater, second floor, 107 Suffolk Street, Lower East Side. Tickets: $10; $8 for children. Reservations: (212) 260-4080, extension 14.

''THE LAND OF SMILES,'' a musical with rod and hand puppets by the puppeteer-singer Susan Delery Whedon,Saturdays and Sundays at noon and 1:30 p.m., through June 25. Papageno Puppet Theater, 462 Columbus Avenue, near 82nd Street, Manhattan. Tickets: $6. Reservations required: (212) 874-3297.

''MIDSUMMER IN THE KEY OF DREAMS,'' a new work based on Shakespeare's comedy ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' is set in Brooklyn's Prospect Park and performed by students of the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music's Teen Theater and Instrumental Workshop. Tonight at 7 at the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music, 58 Seventh Avenue, Park Slope. Information: (718) 622-3300. Free.

''THE TORTOISE AND THE HARE'' and other Aesop's fables, including ''Androcles and the Lion'' and ''The Milkmaid and Her Pail,'' will be presented by Puppetworks, Saturdays at 12:30 and 2:30 p.m. through Aug. 26. Puppetworks, 338 Sixth Avenue, at Fourth Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. For 3 and older. Admission: $7; $5 for children; $4.25 for groups of 20 or more. Reservations suggested: (718) 965-3391.

''Y2KIDS: STORIES AND SONGS FOR THE NEW MILLENNIUM,'' a show that is part musical revue, part drama and part poetry recitation, is performed by members of New York Youth Theater's junior company, who are 5 to 11 years old. Today at 7 p.m.; tomorrow at 1 and 5 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Central Presbyterian Church, seventh floor, 593 Park Avenue, at 64th Street. Tickets: $10. Reservations: (212) 888-0696.
Events

ART INSPIRATIONS. After learning how art inspired the novelist Herman Melville, children will create their own paintings, tomorrow and Sunday, 1 to 4 p.m. at the South Street Seaport Museum's Children's Center, 165 John Street, Lower Manhattan. Free with museum admission: $6; the elderly, $5; students, $4; children 12 and under, $3; also a $3 materials fee. Information: (212) 748-8600; reservations for special events: (212) 748-8786.

BACK PORCH CRAFT SERIES, Saturdays in June at 1 p.m. at the Dyckman Farmhouse, Broadway and 204th Street, Inwood, will focus on traditional 18th-century crafts. Tomorrow children and adults can relax on the back porch of the Dutch Colonial farmhouse and learn about woodcarving. Free. Information: (212) 304-9422.

BIRD TALES. Visitors can enjoy bird stories tomorrow at noon during a stroll through the Queens Botanical Garden's Bird Garden, 43-50 Main Street, Flushing. Participants will also gather materials -- similar to what birds use for their nests -- to make a handmade picture frame for Father's Day. Fee: $3. On weekends a trolley runs to Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Information: (718) 886-3800.

''BOJANGLES BEAT,'' a celebration of the legacy of the tap dancer Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, is the final season program of Lincoln Center's Reel to Real family series, which combines films with live performances and audience participation. Young tap wizards -- including Baakari Wilder, star of Broadway's ''Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk,'' the Little Rhythm Kings and Moscow's Sergei and Vasili -- will dance along with the celluloid Robinson. Tomorrow at 11:30 a.m. and 2 p.m. Tickets: $12; $6 for children 4 to 14. Information: (212) 875-5370.

CIRCUS SUNDAYS IN JUNE. Comic magicians, Brazilian stilt-dancers, jugglers and a virtuoso on cowbells will perform at 2 and 4 p.m. at Red Hook's Waterfront Museum and Showboat Barge (the historic 1914 Lehigh Valley Railroad Barge No. 79), docked at the foot of Conover Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, rain or shine. A Con Ed shuttle bus will offer a free ride to the barge from Park Slope, Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill, Carroll Gardens and Red Hook. Ringside reservations: $5; free seating at showtime. Information: (718) 624-4719.

''CONQUEST OF THE PLANET OF THE APES,'' the 1972 science-fiction film starring Roddy McDowall as the leader of an ape revolt, will be shown on Sunday at 2 p.m. The movie is part of the ''Movies for Kids'' series of science-fiction films presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. Tickets: $3. Walter Reade Theater, at Lincoln Center. Information: (212) 875-5601.

CRIME LAB INVESTIGATION. Sleuths in the making solve a simulated crime mystery by collecting evidence, rounding up suspects and analyzing a ransom note, Sunday from 10:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street. Even detectives get hungry, so participants, ages 8 and 9, should bring a bag lunch. Fee: $15. Information and registration: (212) 769-5200.

A GARDEN OF SHAPES. After viewing the June blooms at Wave Hill, West 249th Street and Independence Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx, youngsters can sketch or combine shapes to create a mixed-media garden collage tomorrow and Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. Free with admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; Saturdays, free until noon. Information: (718) 549-3200; reservations: extension 213.

MEER WONDERS. Youngsters can learn about the natural and wildlife wonders of Central Park in a journey around the Harlem Meer tomorrow from 1 to 2:30 p.m. at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, 110th Street near Fifth Avenue, (212) 860-1370. Free.

MILLENNIUM MARBLES TOURNAMENT, an attempt to surpass the Guinness Book of Records entry for the most people to play marbles at the same time in the same place. It will also be part of the 18th Annual Welcome Back to Brooklyn festival, Sunday from 1 to 4 p.m. at Grand Army Plaza at the junction of Flatbush Avenue and Eastern Parkway. The record is 569 people. Registration begins at noon, with warm-up tutorial sessions from 1 to 2 p.m. Information: (718) 855-7882. The No. 2 and No. 3 trains and the B41 and B69 buses go to Grand Army Plaza. Free.

NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY EVENTS take place tomorrow at Manhattan branches. Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53rd Street, (212) 621-0618 or (212) 621-0636, at 3 p.m., ''Meet the Author-Illustrator: Bernard Waber,'' the author of ''Lyle, Lyle, Crocodile,'' who will draw pictures and talk about his books. For children 5 to 8. At the Roosevelt Island Branch, 524 Main Street, (212) 308-6243, at 2 p.m., Lou Gallo, a singer-guitarist, will sing songs for children, and from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m., children can register for a summer reading program. The Yorkville Branch, 222 East 79th Street, (212) 744-5824, will offer ''Hansel and Gretel,'' a puppet show by Ellen van Wees with Czech-style marionettes. For children 3 to 8. Free.

ROCKING THE BOAT AND HARLEM RIVER HIGHBRIDGE CELEBRATION, tomorrow from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. at Roberto Clemente State Park, West Tremont Avenue at 179th Street, the Bronx. Festivities include the launching of a 14-foot boat hand-made from white oak by 16 students. There will also be a mask and puppet show, an appearance by Pete Seeger and Caribbean food. Free. Information: (718) 299-8750.

''STORY CORNER: NEW YORK STORIES.'' Storytellers surrounded by paintings of New York scenery from Colonial times to the present will entertain children with tales about New York City's various communities tomorrow at 4 p.m. in the fifth-floor American Paintings galleries at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park. Free with museum admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2; under 12, free. Information: (718) 638-5000.

TRIX CIRCO MUNDIAL is a single-ring circus where stunts, trapeze acts and acrobatics are presented with Latin-flavored live music and costumes. Most of the performers are from Central or South America, Spain, the Spanish-speaking Caribbean or Hispanic-American communities. Tomorrow night at 7:30; Sunday at noon, 3:30 and 7:30 p.m.; Tuesday through Friday, 4 and 7:30 p.m. There may be changes because of the weather; for information, call (888) 959-0595. Through June 18 at Shea Stadium, 123-01 Roosevelt Avenue, Parking Lot C, Flushing, Queens. June 21 through July 2 at Macombs Dam Park, 40 East 164th Street, across from Yankee Stadium in the Bronx. Tickets: $16 to 25; for ages under 10, $14 to $22.50.
